metadata.title: LT: Completing Your Rollover Online – Best Practices

summary.purpose: Help the agent guide participants through completing an online rollover of their ForUsAll 401(k) to another retirement account and avoid common errors with wire or check instructions.
key_business_rules: Use the Separation of Service option under Termination Distribution only if the participant has already left the employer.
If the participant is still employed and wants to roll over eligible funds such as rollover source balances, they must contact ForUsAll Support before proceeding.
Participants must choose the appropriate distribution type: Cash Withdrawal, Rollover, or Split; cash withdrawals are subject to taxes.
The receiving account, such as an IRA or new employer 401(k), should be open before the participant submits the rollover request.
When entering the Financial Institution, the participant must not include FBO [Your Name] because this will be added automatically to the paperwork.

For wire rollovers, participants must use wire-specific routing and account numbers obtained from the receiving provider; using incorrect or ACH-only instructions can cause the wire to be rejected and reissued by check, adding delays.
Traditional and Roth funds must roll over into matching account types, and IRA or Roth IRA rollovers require the correct account number.
key_steps_summary: Have the participant log in to their ForUsAll account at forusall.com/login using a computer with an up-to-date browser.

From the dashboard, direct them to Loans & Distributions, ensure they are in the correct plan, and have them select Separation of Service under Termination Distribution if they have left the employer.
Have the participant choose the distribution type (Cash Withdrawal, Rollover, or Split) and select whether the rollover will be full or partial.

Tell the participant to gather and enter accurate rollover destination details, including institution information, routing and account numbers, and mailing address depending on whether they are using a wire or check.

Have the participant review all information carefully, then submit the request and allow for typical processing timelines of about 7–10 business days for wires or ACH and 2–3 weeks for standard checks.

high_impact_faq_pairs.question: Which option should a participant select if they left their employer and want to move their 401(k) to an IRA?
high_impact_faq_pairs.answer: They should use Separation of Service under Termination Distribution, choose Rollover as the distribution type, and then enter the IRA details provided by their new institution.

high_impact_faq_pairs.question: Should a participant include FBO [My Name] in the Financial Institution field?
high_impact_faq_pairs.answer: No, they should enter only the provider name in the Financial Institution field; the FBO [Your Name] language is added automatically to the paperwork.

high_impact_faq_pairs.question: How long does an online rollover usually take to complete?
high_impact_faq_pairs.answer: Wire or ACH rollovers typically complete within about 7–10 business days, while standard checks usually arrive within about 2–3 weeks via USPS.

high_impact_faq_pairs.question: What should a participant do if the financial institution name or address is too long for the available fields?
high_impact_faq_pairs.answer: They should contact their new provider, such as Fidelity, Schwab, or Vanguard, to ask if the name or address can be abbreviated so it fits within the system limits.

high_impact_faq_pairs.question: What details are required for a rollover by wire?
high_impact_faq_pairs.answer: They need the receiving institution name, wire-specific ABA routing number, bank account number, subaccount or IRA account number, and the name of the bank that receives wires on behalf of the provider, all confirmed with the receiving institution.

plan_specific_guardrails: Do not instruct participants to use the Separation of Service option if they are still employed; instead, direct them to contact ForUsAll Support to confirm any rollover eligibility.
Do not tell participants to type FBO [Your Name] or similar text into the Financial Institution field because that language is automatically included on the paperwork.
Do not tell participants that they can roll traditional funds into Roth-only accounts or Roth funds into traditional-only accounts; traditional and Roth funds must roll into matching account types.
Do not promise processing times shorter than those stated; communicate that wires and ACH typically take 7–10 business days and standard checks usually arrive within 2–3 weeks.

rules: The Separation of Service option under Termination Distribution should only be selected if the participant has already left the employer.
Participants who are still employed but want to roll over eligible funds such as rollover source balances must contact ForUsAll Support first to confirm their eligibility.
The receiving account, such as an IRA or a new employer 401(k), should already be open before the participant submits a rollover request.
Participants must choose one of three distribution types: Cash Withdrawal, Rollover, or Split Option.
Cash Withdrawal means funds are sent directly to the participant and are subject to taxes.
Rollover means funds are transferred to another qualified retirement account such as an IRA or a new employer 401(k).
The Split Option allows part of the balance to be rolled over and part to be paid out in cash.
Participants can choose between a Full Rollover, which transfers the entire account balance, and a Partial Rollover, which transfers only part of the balance and leaves the rest in the 401(k).
Choosing the wrong rollover type may delay processing or require the rollover to be reprocessed.
Participants are encouraged to complete the rollover using a computer or laptop rather than a mobile device and to use an up-to-date browser such as Chrome or Edge.
If the Loans & Distributions section does not load, the participant should refresh the browser or clear the cache before retrying.
Participants with more than one 401(k) through ForUsAll must double-check that they are accessing the correct plan before initiating a rollover.
Some fields, such as the financial institution name or address, have character limits that may require abbreviations.
Participants should contact their new provider to confirm whether long names or addresses can be abbreviated so that entries fit within these limits.
In the Financial Institution field, participants must list only the provider name and must not include text such as FBO [Your Name] because that language is added automatically to the paperwork.
Participants should double-check bank details, especially for wire transfers, to ensure they are using the correct routing and account numbers.
Participants should verify all information before submitting the request to avoid delays or corrections.
Wire or ACH rollover transfers are typically completed within about 7–10 business days.
Standard rollover checks usually arrive within approximately 2–3 weeks via USPS.
Most rollovers complete within about 7–10 business days after approval, depending on the method and any corrections that may be needed.
When selecting a wire transfer, accurate instructions are especially important.
Participants should obtain the correct wire instructions from their new provider before entering any details.
Many financial institutions have different instructions for wires versus ACH or direct deposit, and participants must use the wire-specific details.
For a rollover by wire, participants must enter the bank account name, which is the name of the receiving institution such as Fidelity or Vanguard.
Participants must enter the ABA routing number that the receiving institution uses for wires.
Participants must enter the bank account number that the receiving institution uses for wires.
Participants must enter the subaccount number, which is their IRA or Roth IRA account number, and this must be accurate.
Participants must enter the financial institution that receives the wire on behalf of their provider when applicable.
If incorrect wire instructions are used, the funds may be rejected and reissued by check, which can add delays.
Participants should always verify all wire details directly with the receiving institution before submitting the request.
For rollovers by check, participants must enter the financial institution that will receive the rollover, such as Fidelity or Vanguard.
Participants must enter the street address for the receiving institution or their own address if they want the check mailed directly to them.
When selecting Rollover To, participants must choose from IRA, Qualified Plan, Roth IRA, or Roth Qualified Plan, based on whether the funds are traditional or Roth.
If the participant selects IRA or Roth IRA, they must include the account number for that IRA.

Traditional funds must roll over into traditional-only account types, such as IRA or Qualified Plan, and Roth funds must roll over into Roth-only account types, such as Roth IRA or Roth Qualified Plan.

steps.description: Have the participant go to forusall.com/login and sign in to their ForUsAll account using their credentials.
steps.notes: Recommend using a computer or laptop rather than a mobile device and suggest an up-to-date browser such as Chrome or Edge for the best experience.

steps.description: From the participant dashboard, have them click Loans & Distributions in the top-right area.
steps.notes: If the Loans & Distributions section does not load, advise them to refresh the browser or clear the cache and try again, and confirm that they have selected the correct plan if they have more than one 401(k) through ForUsAll.

steps.description: Under Termination Distribution, direct the participant to select Separation of Service and click Get Started if they have already left the employer.
steps.notes: Emphasize that Separation of Service should only be used after the participant has left the employer; if they are still employed but interested in rolling over eligible funds such as rollover sources, instruct them to contact ForUsAll Support first.

steps.description: Have the participant choose the appropriate distribution type: Cash Withdrawal, Rollover, or Split Option.
steps.notes: Explain that Cash Withdrawal sends funds directly to the participant and is subject to taxes, while Rollover transfers funds to another qualified retirement account and Split allows part of the balance to be rolled over and part to be paid out in cash; encourage them to confirm with the receiving provider how they prefer to receive the rollover, by check or wire, before finalizing this section.

steps.description: Have the participant select whether the rollover will be a Full Rollover or a Partial Rollover as appropriate for their situation.
steps.notes: Clarify that a Full Rollover moves the entire account balance, while a Partial Rollover moves only part of the balance and leaves the rest in the 401(k); remind them that choosing the wrong type can delay processing or require reprocessing.

steps.description: If the participant is rolling over by wire, guide them to enter the required wire details from the receiving institution.
steps.notes: Instruct them to obtain and enter the receiving institution name, the wire-specific ABA routing number, the bank account number used for wires, their subaccount or IRA account number, and the name of the bank that receives wires on behalf of the provider if applicable; stress that they must use wire instructions rather than ACH or direct deposit instructions and verify all information with the receiving institution.

steps.description: If the participant is rolling over by check, guide them to enter the required check details.
steps.notes: They should enter the financial institution that will receive the rollover, the correct mailing address for that institution or their own address if they want the check sent directly to them, and select the correct Rollover To option: IRA, Qualified Plan, Roth IRA, or Roth Qualified Plan, making sure traditional funds go to traditional accounts and Roth funds go to Roth accounts; if they choose IRA or Roth IRA, they must also enter the corresponding account number.

steps.description: Have the participant review all rollover details carefully before submitting the request.
steps.notes: Remind them to verify that institution names and addresses fit within character limits, that they did not type FBO [Your Name] in the Financial Institution field, and that all routing, account, and subaccount numbers match the instructions provided by the receiving institution; once submitted, explain the typical processing timeline of 7–10 business days for wires or ACH and 2–3 weeks for standard checks, and advise them to contact ForUsAll Support if they need help confirming details.

common_issues.issue: The Loans & Distributions section does not load when the participant clicks it.
common_issues.resolution: Ask the participant to refresh their browser or clear their cache and try again, and confirm that they are accessing the correct plan if they have more than one 401(k) through ForUsAll.

common_issues.issue: The participant selects the Separation of Service option even though they are still employed.
common_issues.resolution: Explain that Separation of Service is only for participants who have already left the employer and advise them to contact ForUsAll Support to discuss whether any eligible funds can be rolled over while they are still employed.

common_issues.issue: The financial institution name or address does not fit in the available fields due to character limits.
common_issues.resolution: Inform the participant that some fields have character limits and advise them to contact their new provider to see whether the name or address can be abbreviated so it fits without causing rejections or manual corrections.

common_issues.issue: The participant types FBO [Your Name] into the Financial Institution field.
common_issues.resolution: Advise the participant to remove the FBO language and enter only the provider name in the Financial Institution field, noting that the FBO language will appear automatically on the paperwork.

common_issues.issue: The participant provides ACH or direct deposit instructions instead of wire-specific details for a wire rollover.
common_issues.resolution: Explain that many providers use different instructions for wires and ACH and instruct the participant to contact their receiving institution to obtain wire-specific routing and account numbers, then update the rollover request with those wire details.

common_issues.issue: The participant is unsure whether to choose Cash Withdrawal, Rollover, or Split Option.
common_issues.resolution: Describe that Cash Withdrawal sends money directly to them and is subject to taxes, while Rollover sends funds to another qualified retirement account and Split combines both, and recommend that they confirm their choice with their receiving institution or contact ForUsAll Support if they are still unsure.

examples.scenario: A participant who has left their employer wants to move their entire 401(k) balance to a Fidelity IRA using a wire transfer.
examples.outcome: Advise them to log in to forusall.com/login, go to Loans & Distributions, select Separation of Service under Termination Distribution, choose Rollover as the distribution type, and select a Full Rollover; instruct them to obtain Fidelity's wire instructions, including the receiving institution name, the bank that receives wires on Fidelity's behalf such as JP Morgan Chase, the ABA routing number and bank account number for wires, and their Fidelity IRA account number as the subaccount, and to enter all of these wire-specific details exactly as provided before submitting the request.

examples.scenario: A participant is still employed but wants to roll over some rollover source balances from their current 401(k).
examples.outcome: Explain that the Separation of Service option is only for participants who have already left the employer and instruct them to contact ForUsAll Support to confirm whether any in-plan rollover options are available and how to proceed rather than starting a Separation of Service distribution on their own.

examples.scenario: A participant wants the rollover check sent directly to their home instead of to the receiving institution.
examples.outcome: Advise them that when completing a rollover by check they can enter their own mailing address instead of the institution's address so that the check is mailed directly to them, and remind them to still specify the correct financial institution and Rollover To type and to include an IRA or Roth IRA account number if applicable.

notes: Wire or ACH rollovers are generally faster and are described as typically completing within 7-10 business days.
Standard checks are slower and usually arrive within about 2–3 weeks via USPS.
Most rollovers are expected to complete within roughly 7–10 business days after approval, though delays can occur if corrections or reissues are needed.
Encourage participants to use a desktop or laptop computer with an up-to-date browser such as Chrome or Edge when completing the online rollover.
Remind participants to confirm that they are working in the correct ForUsAll plan if they have multiple 401(k) accounts.

Suggest that participants contact their new provider in advance to obtain all necessary wire or check instructions and to confirm whether long institution names or addresses can be abbreviated to fit within field limits.
Many financial institutions publish separate instructions for wire transfers and ACH or direct deposit, and participants must use the wire-specific details when requesting a rollover by wire.
If wire instructions are entered incorrectly, the rollover may be rejected and funds may be reissued by check, adding extra processing time.

faq_pairs.question: What information should a participant gather from their new provider before starting an online rollover?
faq_pairs.answer: They should gather details on whether the provider prefers to receive rollovers by wire or by check, the exact name of the receiving institution, any required abbreviations for long names or addresses, and the full set of wire or check instructions, including routing numbers, bank account numbers, subaccount or IRA account numbers, mailing address, and which bank receives wires on the provider's behalf if applicable.

faq_pairs.question: Can a participant have the rollover check mailed directly to their home address instead of to the receiving institution?
faq_pairs.answer: Yes, when completing a rollover by check they can enter their own street address as the mailing address so the check is sent directly to them, while still listing the financial institution that will receive the rollover and choosing the correct Rollover To type.

faq_pairs.question: What happens if a participant uses incorrect wire instructions for their rollover?
faq_pairs.answer: If incorrect wire instructions are used, the funds may be rejected by the receiving bank and reissued by check instead, which can add delays to the overall processing time.

faq_pairs.question: Do traditional and Roth funds need to go to different types of accounts in a rollover?
faq_pairs.answer: Yes, traditional funds must be rolled into traditional-only accounts such as IRA or Qualified Plan, and Roth funds must be rolled into Roth-only accounts such as Roth IRA or Roth Qualified Plan, and the participant must choose the appropriate Rollover To option accordingly.

faq_pairs.question: Who should a participant contact if they are unsure which distribution type or rollover method to choose?
faq_pairs.answer: They should contact ForUsAll Support by email or phone for help confirming their rollover details, and they may also check with their receiving provider on how they prefer to receive the rollover.

definitions.definition: A termination distribution option used when a participant has left their employer and wants to take a distribution or rollover from the 401(k).
A rollover that transfers the participant's entire 401(k) account balance to another retirement account.
A rollover that transfers only part of the participant's 401(k) balance to another retirement account, leaving the remaining balance in the 401(k).
The provider or bank that will receive the rollover funds, such as Fidelity, Schwab, or Vanguard, and whose name is entered in the Financial Institution field without FBO language.
The participant's IRA or Roth IRA account number used by the receiving institution to credit the incoming rollover correctly.
A method of electronically sending money between banks using wire-specific routing and account numbers, often used for rollover processing.
A method of electronic payment known as Automated Clearing House that often uses different instructions from wires and is typically used for direct deposit rather than wire rollovers.

must_not: Must not tell participants to select Separation of Service if they are still employed; instead they should be directed to contact ForUsAll Support to confirm what rollover options, if any, are available.
Must not instruct participants to include FBO [Your Name] or similar language in the Financial Institution field, because that language is automatically added to the paperwork.
Must not suggest that traditional funds can be rolled into Roth-only accounts or that Roth funds can be rolled into traditional-only accounts; the account type must match the fund type.
Must not guarantee faster processing times than those given; agents should reference the stated timelines of 7–10 business days for wires or ACH and 2–3 weeks for standard checks.
must_do_if_unsure: If there is any doubt about a participant's eligibility to use Separation of Service or to roll over funds while still employed, the agent must direct the participant to contact ForUsAll Support.

If there is uncertainty about the correct wire or check instructions, the agent must advise the participant to verify all details directly with the receiving institution before submitting the request.

If the participant is unsure which distribution type or rollover method best fits their situation, the agent should recommend that they contact ForUsAll Support and consult their receiving provider for guidance.
